title: DataStax Presents: Prometheus and Cassandra with Luc Perkins
description:
Over the past few years, Prometheus has emerged as a best-of-breed OSS monitoring and observability solution. In this talk, I'll walk you through setting up a full-fledged Prometheus setup for a Cassandra cluster running on Kubernetes, including Grafana dashboards, Alertmanager notifications via Slack, and more.

ABOUT DATASTAX ENTERPRISE 6
DataStax  powers  the  Right-Now  Enterprise  with  the  always-on,  distributed  cloud  database  built  on  Apache  Cassandra™  and designed for hybrid cloud. DataStax Enterprise 6 (DSE 6) includes industry-leading performance, self-driving operational simplicity, and robust analytics.

Learn more at http://www.datastax.com/products/datastax-enterprise and https://www.datastax.com/products/datastax-enterprise-6

CONNECT WITH DATASTAX
Subscribe: http://www.youtube.com/c/datastax?sub_confirmation=1 
Site: http://datastax.com 
Facebook: https://facebook.com/datastax 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/datastax | https://twitter.com/datastax-academy
Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/company/datastax
http://feeds.feedburner.com/datastax 
https://github.com/datastax 

ABOUT DATASTAX ACADEMY
On the DataStax Academy YouTube channel, you can find tutorials, webinars and much more to help you learn and stay updated with the latest information on DataStax Enterprise©.  Create an account on https://academy.datastax.com to watch our free online courses, tutorials, and more.

there may be holdouts there may be advantages that I'm not aware of but I think that the that this label based system which is a you know very much a key-value kind of paradigm for for fetching time are so if you have you know hundreds if not thousands of targets then then how do you make sure that Prometheus knows where they are at all times and there are a bunch of built in mechanisms for doing this you can do basic kubernetes service discovery via the you know default the SVC dot whatever system whatever the weird internal DNS system in kubernetes is you can use console you can use standard DNS or one that I find super interesting is you can actually use JSON files for service discovery so you can basically say so you can just in your service discovery configuration you can point to a JSON file and list you know IPs and imports alongside that and which is which is already fairly compelling but but what I find more compelling is that if you if you change these if you change the updates via JSON files so you know some kind of you know either like kubernetes you know pod sidecar or some kind of you know agent running on a particular server it's actually it's you know has a sole task of keeping these JSON files up-to-date at all times so I think that's another very cool of customization thing so and finally amongst the this is not going to be like five parts just two adding feature after feature after feature they want to you know their goal is kind of the same as the kubernetes core team which is basically they want to just have a a feature set that's done web hooks if you need to instead of you know hard coding a bunch of of alerting targets into alert manager and you know getting that static binary blowed it to like 150 megabytes instead they just let you write your own there's also a a remote a remote write API I'm taking trigger water real quick there's a remote write API for long-term storage so Prometheus does not actually provide any long-term storage you can configure how long you want your data to stay in a particular Prometheus instance but it's not designed for to keep your data around forever and to run super complex queries on data that's a month old it's meant to basically take taken as much data as you say for it to take in process it the way it needs to process it potentially fire off alerts and then just let it go after while or potentially write it to a long-term storage solution file based service discovery is the one is another one that I just mentioned I am not aware of any other systems that do file based service discovery in this way does anybody know of one where you can update a file and that change is instantly noted by the system and taken yeah I haven't seen them before which is super cool and and of course custom exporters so so lots of things including Cassandra and you know every other major database and major distributed system thing that you can think of has a Prometheus exporter and you can also just create your own so as long as you know as long as you expose an HTTP port that's scrape Abul by Prometheus and you expose your metrics in the the Prometheus text format then you have written a Prometheus scrape compatible service or process so some of the drawbacks of Prometheus and of course I put the asterisk because drawbacks you know really depend on your perspective and and some of the so-called drawbacks are actually a product of you know very conscious decision making on their part so there's no built in long term storage it's not designed for that it's not it's not it's not built around that principle it's also not importantly it's technically not a highly available system so each each Prometheus node is like an independent sort of universe they're not built to work in conjunction with one another they're not built to work in a cluster you don't get you don't nrw you know read/write quorums specifics or semantics or anything like that you basically you get high you get high availability by just running lots of them and if you lose one you just you know you just hope for the best that there's still enough left which is also I think a very conscious decision on the part of the developers that when you start building system to operate in terms of you know Paxos or raft or or whatever consensus algorithm they get really hairy really quickly they they produce all kinds of headaches for four operators and sres and sis admins and yeah so no no built in long-term storage is a drawback but like I said there is a remote I remote right API that you can use to to fan-out Prometheus data and to any kind of system you want so some of the major commercial providers include in flux DB which I'm sure a lot of you are familiar with they have I think a pretty good prometheus story there's an open source project called open TS d TS DB a time series database you can use actually other systems like graphite for that so on and so forth and yeah basically you can you can shell that data out any way you like with the API there's also this is also a little bit controversial but but there's no built-in security so this is another design choice that keeps that that static binary nice and lean and keeps it very quote unquote I guess operationally simple but it also means that that any security that goes on around prometheus has to be provided by by you so it basically assumes that that every request in everything coming to it is coming from some kind of you know trusted non-malicious non-malignant source and and yeah the responsibility is on you to to keep it that way so the drawback of course is that that's another operational thing that you have to that you have to worry about and take care of but I guess the advantage is that if you have some you know crazy you know like Kerberos level 10 internal security system that you don't have to you know that the Prometheus maintainer don't have to worry about covering that another drawback is the sort of plaintext metrics x-position format now it's a super simple format I showed you a couple examples but one of the criticisms here of course is that it would probably be a lot faster if if the metrics were exposed by a you know protobuf or or something like that some something some kind of more efficient encoding would probably be better which yeah I I suppose that is a drawback but it does have the advantage that that writing your own you know libraries that work with your own language specific libraries and and clients for Prometheus is super easy because you're just writing plain text and not having to you know do your dot proto something or other and then finally one drawback I guess is that it tends to be just one piece of a puzzle so this is not like an all-encompassing all-in-one tool that's meant to to serve every purpose there's no built-in dashboard you use Cortana for that there's no support for logs or tracing so you know if you want to deal with logs you're gonna have to do a log stash elasticsearch something or other if you want to do tracing you're gonna have to do Jagr some kind of open tracing compatible thing etc so in terms of how
